qas.question: What are some spinal cord fibers exclusive to?
Pain signals travel first to what region of the brain?
Where does pain-related activity in the thalamus spread to?
Pain which is distinctly located also activates what cortices?
Where do pain signals travel up to from the thalamus?
What are dynamic wide range neurons?
What signals do the A-delta fibers carry?
What does the cingulate cortex anterior embody?
Whose 1986 picture of pain is influential today?

context: Spinal cord fibers dedicated to carrying <a0_0>A-delta<a0_0/> fiber pain signals, and others that carry both A-delta and C fiber pain signals up <b5_0>the spinal cord<b5_0/> to the <a1_0>thalamus<a1_0/> in the brain have been identified. <b6_0>Other <a2_0>spinal cord fibers<b6_0/><a2_0/>, known as wide dynamic range neurons, respond to A-delta and C fibers, but also to the large A-beta fibers that carry <b7_0>touch, pressure and vibration<b7_0/> signals. Pain-related activity in the thalamus spreads to <a3_0>the insular cortex<a3_0/> (thought to embody, among other things, the feeling that distinguishes pain from other homeostatic emotions such as itch and nausea) and anterior cingulate cortex (thought to embody, among other things, <b8_0>the motivational element of pain<b8_0/>); and pain that is distinctly located also activates the primary and secondary <a4_0>somatosensory<a4_0/> cortices. <b9_0>Melzack and Casey<b9_0/>'s 1968 picture of the dimensions of pain is as influential today as ever, firmly framing theory and guiding research in the functional neuroanatomy and psychology of pain.
